Author: Akoachere Jane-Francis Tatah Kihla, Palle John Ngunde, Mbianda Soupsop Evelyn, Nkwelang Gerard, Roland Ndip Ndip
Title of paper: Risk factors for wound infection in health care facilities in Buea, Cameroon: aerobic bacterial pathogens and antibiogram of isolates
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on purulent discharge or signs of inflammation (erythema, pain, tenderness, warmth or induration); aerobic bacterial culture

Author: Kachipedzu Amos Tumizani, David King Kulapani, Samuel James Meja, Janelisa Musaya
Title of paper: Surgical site infection and antimicrobial use following caesarean section at QECH in Blantyre, Malawi: a prospective cohort study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: 30-day clinical follow-up and microbiological wound culture using CDC criteria

Author: Hope Derick, Lucas Ampaire, Caesar Oyet, Enoch Muwanguzi, Hillary Twizerimana, Richard Onyuthi Apecu
Title of paper: Antimicrobial resistance in pathogenic aerobic bacteria causing surgical site infections in Mbarara regional referral hospital, Southwestern Uganda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Guidelines on prevention of SSI by CDC and protocol by European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC); clinical diagnosis with bacteriological confirmation using wound swabs and standard microbiological techniques

Author: Odoko Desta, Abera Kumalo, Getachew Alemu, Tigistu Demisse, Teshale Mulugeta, Muluneh Temesgen
Title of paper: Extended-spectrum ß-lactamase and carbapenemase producing Enterobacteriaceae among patients suspected with surgical site infection at Hospitals in Southern Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical criteria per CDC guidelines; laboratory confirmation by culture of wound swabs/aspirates

Author: Dinda Victor, Gunturu Revathi, Kariuki Sam, Hakeem Abdi, Raja Asad, Kimang'a Andrew
Title of paper: Pattern of Pathogens and their Sensitivity Isolated from Surgical Site Infections at the Aga Khan University Hospital, Nairobi, Kenya
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Diagnosis by surgeon according to CDC definition; clinical assessment and laboratory confirmation (culture of pus swabs)

Author: Gentilotti Elisa, Pasquale De Nardo, Boniface Nguhuni, Alessandro Piscini, Caroline Damian, Francesco Vairo, Zainab Chaula, Paola Mencarini, Peter Torokaa, Alimuddin Zumla, Emanuele Nicastri, Giuseppe Ippolito
Title of paper: Implementing a combined infection prevention and control with antimicrobial stewardship joint program to prevent caesarean section surgical site infections and antimicrobial resistance: a Tanzanian tertiary hospital experience
Method of SSI Diagnosis: CDC criteria, clinical wound examination by infectious diseases specialist, structured telephone interview; wound swab for culture in suspected cases
Economic - direct costs: Estimated hospital cost savings of €1500 during post-intervention (by switching from 3 days IV antibiotics post-op to single-dose pre-op prophylaxis)
Economic - indirect costs: Estimated personal saving of €3 per patient due to reduction in post-discharge antibiotic prescriptions

Author: Gemedo Misha, Legese Chelkeba, Tsegaye Melaku
Title of paper: Bacterial profile and antimicrobial susceptibility patterns of isolates among patients diagnosed with surgical site infection at a tertiary teaching hospital in Ethiopia: a prospective cohort study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment by attending physician using CDC SSI surveillance methods and criteria
Economic - direct costs: Extra costs due to SSI of between 800 and £ 7000 have been recorded (citation from literature, not new data)

Author: Haitham Hamudu, Helmut Nyawale, Vitus Silago, Mariam M. Mirambo, Phillipo L. Chalya, Stephen E. Mshana
Title of paper: Incidence, bacteriological profile and predictors of surgical site infections following limb amputation at Bugando medical centre and Sekou toure referral regional hospital, Mwanza, Tanzania
Method of SSI Diagnosis: CDC criteria with clinical assessment and wound/pus swab for culture

Author: Ojulong Julius, T.P. Mwambu, M. Joloba, F. Bwanga, D.H. Kaddu-Mulindwa
Title of paper: Relative prevalence of methicilline resistant Staphylococcus aureus and its susceptibility pattern in Mulago Hospital, Kampala, Uganda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis with collection of pus swabs for microbiological identification
Economic - direct costs: High cost and unavailability of alternative antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin) noted as an economic treatment consideration

Author: Iyamba Jean-Marie Liesse, José Mulwahali Wambale, Cyprien Mbundu Lukukula, Ntondo za Balega Takaisi-Kikuni
Title of paper: High prevalence of methicillin resistant staphylococci strains isolated from surgical site infections in Kinshasa
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Wound swab collection from purulent infected sites; laboratory identification of staphylococcal strains using standard microbiological methods and latex agglutination test

Author: Manyahi Joel, Mecky I Matee, Mtebe Majigo, Sabrina Moyo, Stephen E Mshana, Eligius F Lyamuya
Title of paper: Predominance of multi-drug resistant bacterial pathogens causing surgical site infections in Muhimbili national hospital, Tanzania
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical evidence as defined by CDC criteria

Author: Boru Kalicha, Alqeer Aliyo, Derese Daka, Tibeso Gamachu, Oliyad Husen, Zekarias Solomon
Title of paper: Bacterial surgical site infections: prevalence, antimicrobial susceptibility patterns, and associated risk factors among patients at Bule Hora University Teaching Hospital, Southern Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment by physician; features including pain, redness, swelling, discharge, fever; followed CDC (and WHO) criteria; culture confirmation
Economic - indirect costs: Loss of daily wages mentioned as an impact but no quantitative data provided

Author: Velin Lotta, Theoneste Nkurunziza, Grace Umutesi, Gilbert Rukundo, Robert Riviello, Jean De Dieu Gatete, Moses Muwanguzi, Ivan Emil, Lisa M. Bebell, Bethany L. Hedt-Gauthier, Marthe Yankurije, Fredrick Kateera, Kara Faktor
Title of paper: Surgical Site Infections and Antimicrobial Resistance After Cesarean Section Delivery in Rural Rwanda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis by trained GPs using CDC guidelines; confirmed by wound examination at POD 11 (+/- 3 days)

Author: Mengesha RE, Kasa BG, Saravanan M, Berhe DF, Wasihun AG
Title of paper: Aerobic bacteria in post surgical wound infections and pattern of their antimicrobial susceptibility in Ayder Teaching and Referral Hospital, Mekelle, Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis by physicians (symptoms of infection), with confirmation by wound swab aerobic culture

Author: Scherbaum Micha, Katrin Kösters, Raymund Egid Mürbeth, Ulysse Ateba Ngoa, Peter Gottfried Kremsner, Bertrand Lell, Abraham Alabi
Title of paper: Incidence, pathogens and resistance patterns of nosocomial infections at a rural hospital in Gabon
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment with microbiological confirmation where possible; classification based on Robert Koch Institute definitions as per CDC guidelines

Author: De Nardo P, E. Gentilotti, B. Nguhuni, F. Vairo, Z. Chaula, E. Nicastri, M.M. Nassoro, N. Bevilacqua, A. Ismail, A. Savoldi, A. Zumla, G. Ippolito
Title of paper: Post-caesarean section surgical site infections at a Tanzanian tertiary hospital: a prospective observational study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical examination at follow-up visits, CDC criteria, structured telephone interview and algorithm

Author: Worku Sebele, Tamrat Abebe, Ashenafi Alemu, Berhanu Seyoum, Göte Swedberg, Alemseged Abdissa, Adane Mihret, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene
Title of paper: Bacterial profile of surgical site infection and antimicrobial resistance patterns in Ethiopia: a multicentre prospective cross-sectional study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis by attending physicians; laboratory confirmation by wound discharge culture and identification (MALDI-TOF, Gram stain, biochemical tests)

Author: Worku Sebele, Tamrat Abebe, Berhanu Seyoum, Ashenafi Alemu, Yidenek Shimelash, Marechign Yimer, Alemseged Abdissa, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene, Göte Swedberg, Adane Mihret
Title of paper: Molecular Epidemiology of Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus among Patients Diagnosed with Surgical Site Infection at Four Hospitals in Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis, confirmed by wound culture

Author: Worku Sebele, Tamrat Abebe, Berhanu Seyoum, Bikila Alemu, Gebrie Denkayehu, Tamrayehu Seyoum, Dawit Hailu Alemayehu, Alemseged Abdissa, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene, Adane Mihret, Göte Swedberg
Title of paper: Molecular characterization of carbapenemase and extended spectrum beta-lactamase producing Acinetobacter baumannii isolates causing surgical site infections in Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment by surgeon: infection characterized by pain, redness, edema, tenderness, gaping, abscess/purulent discharge, fever >38°C within 30 days of operation for those without implant

Author: Ali Abdurrahman, Daniel Gebretsadik, Kassu Desta
Title of paper: Incidence of surgical site infection, bacterial isolate, and their antimicrobial susceptibility pattern among patients who underwent surgery at Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital, Northeast Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical evidence of infection by residents using CDC SSI criteria, wound swab for bacteriological confirmation

Author: Kefale Belayneh, Gobezie T Tegegne, Amsalu Degu, Mulugeta Molla, Yitayih Kefale
Title of paper: Surgical Site Infections and Prophylaxis Antibiotic Use in the Surgical Ward of Public Hospital in Western Ethiopia: A Hospital-Based Retrospective Cross-Sectional Study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Medical record review following WHO guideline operational definitions

Author: Billoro, Mengistu Nunemo, Seid E. Gelan
Title of paper: Evaluation of antimicrobial prophylaxis use and rate of surgical site infection in surgical ward of Wachemo University Nigist Eleni Mohammed Memorial Hospital, Southern Ethiopia: prospective cohort study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Diagnosis by WUNEMMH surgeons, wound classification according to CDC criteria, wound specimens collected and cultured for confirmation

Author: Nitrushwa David, Rahel Ghebre, Marie A Unyuzimana, Urania Magriples, Maria Small, Stephen Rulisa
Title of paper: Single vs. extended antibiotic for prevention of surgical infection in emergent cesarean delivery
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Defined as fever, tenderness and swelling of the wound or loss of continuity with pus discharge; assessed at discharge and by phone interview up to day 30

Author: Derick Hope DD, Lucas Ampaire, Caesar Oyet, Enoch Muwanguzi, Hillary Twizerimana, Richard Onyuthi Apecu
Title of paper: Antimicrobial resistance in pathogenic aerobic bacteria causing surgical site infections in Mbarara regional referral hospital, Southwestern Uganda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Guidelines on prevention of SSI by CDC and protocol by European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC); clinical diagnosis with bacteriological confirmation using wound swabs and standard microbiological techniques

Author: Garoy Eyob Yohannes, Yacob Berhane Gebreab, Oliver Okoth Achila, Nobiel Tecklebrhan, Hermon Michael Tsegai, Alex Zecarias Hailu, Abrehet Marikos Buthuamlak, Tewelde Ghide Asfaga, Mohammed Elfatih Hamida
Title of paper: Magnitude of Multidrug Resistance among Bacterial Isolates from Surgical Site Infections in Two National Referral Hospitals in Asmara, Eritrea
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis (infection after 48 hours of admission); confirmation by wound swabs processed by Levine technique and standard microbiological procedures

Author: Habtemariam Alekaw Habteweld, Mohammed Yimam, Abate Wondesen Tsige, Yehualashet Teshome Wondmkun, Bedilu Linger Endalifer, Kassahun Dires Ayenew
Title of paper: Surgical site infection and antimicrobial prophylaxis prescribing profile, and its determinants among hospitalized patients in Northeast Ethiopia: a hospital based cross-sectional study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical signs and symptoms only (no laboratory confirmation)

Author: Hamudu Haitham, Helmut Nyawale, Vitus Silago, Mariam M. Mirambo, Phillipo L. Chalya, Stephen E. Mshana
Title of paper: Incidence, bacteriological profile and predictors of surgical site infections following limb amputation at Bugando medical centre and Sekou toure referral regional hospital, Mwanza, Tanzania
Method of SSI Diagnosis: CDC criteria with clinical assessment and wound/pus swab for culture

Author: Kumburu Happiness Houka, Tolbert Sonda, Blandina Theophil Mmbaga, Michael Alifrangis, Ole Lund, Gibson Kibiki, Frank M. Aarestrup
Title of paper: Patterns of infections, aetiological agents and antimicrobial resistance at a tertiary care hospital in northern Tanzania
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical specimen collection from wounds/swabs; bacterial culture and identification using conventional and biochemical tests

Author: Amulioto Johnstone, Margaret W. Muturi, Scholastica Mathenge, Gideon M. Mutua
Title of paper: Antibiotic susceptibility patterns of bacteria isolates from post-operative wound infections among patients attending Mama Lucy Kibaki Hospital, Kenya
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical evidence of infection (drainage from incision); identified by surgeons

Author: Ojulong Julius, Tom Philip Mwambu, Moses Jolobo, Ezra Agwu, Freddie Bwanga, Christine Najjuka, D.H. Kaddu-Mulindwa
Title of paper: Prevalence of methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) among isolates from surgical site infections in Mulago hospital-Kampala, Uganda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Defined by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) criteria (Horan et al, 1992)

Author: Jung L, Kiwanuka J, Mbabazi L, Nakate V, Musaazi J, Nabaja H, Kajumbula H, Lubbert C, Mwaka E, Nsibirwa S, von Braun A
Title of paper: A case for routine microbial diagnostics: Results from antimicrobial susceptibility testing in post-traumatic wound infections at a Ugandan tertiary care hospital
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Diagnosis based on clinical signs of wound infection (erythema, pus discharge, fever); wound swabs and blood cultures for microbial confirmation

Author: Burugu Magdaline, Andrew Nyerere, Susan Odera, Lameck Ontweka
Title of paper: Occurrence of Post-Surgical Wound Infections, Bacterial Isolates, and their Susceptibility to Commonly Used Antibiotics at Kenyatta National Hospital, Kenya
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical signs (purulent exudate, swelling, erythema, pain, local temperature, peri wound cellulitis) or surgeon's diagnosis

Author: Mukagendaneza Marie Josée , Emmanuel Munyaneza, Esperance Muhawenayo, Dancilla Nyirasebura, Egide Abahuje, John Nyirigira, Jean De Dieu Harelimana, Thierry Zawadi Muvunyi, Florence Masaisa, Jean Claude Byiringiro, Theobald Hategekimana, Claude Mambo Muvunyi
Title of paper: Incidence, root causes, and outcomes of surgical site infections in a tertiary care hospital in Rwanda: a prospective observational cohort study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment and wound swab/culture; SSI classified by CDC criteria (all superficial)

Author: Abayneh Mengistu, Molla Asnake, Dassalegn Muleta, Asnake Simieneh
Title of paper: Assessment of Bacterial Profiles and Antimicrobial Susceptibility Pattern of Isolates Among Patients Diagnosed with Surgical Site Infections at Mizan-Tepi University Teaching Hospital, Southwest Ethiopia: A Prospective Observational Cohort Study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: CDC-NHSN and WHO criteria for SSI; clinical assessment by surgeons and attending physicians; laboratory culture for confirmation

Author: De Nardo P., E. Gentilotti, B. Nguhuni, F. Vairo, Z. Chaula, E. Nicastri, M.M. Nassoro, N. Bevilacqua, A. Ismail, A. Savoldi, A. Zumla, G. Ippolito
Title of paper: Post-caesarean section surgical site infections at a Tanzanian tertiary hospital: a prospective observational study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical examination at follow-up visits, CDC criteria, structured telephone interview and algorithm

Author: Abosse Samuel, Chalachew Genet, Awoke Derbie
Title of paper: Antimicrobial Resistance Profile of Bacterial Isolates Identified from Surgical Site Infections at a Referral Hospital, Northwest Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment and culture confirmation (conventional bacteriological technique)

Author: Worku Seble , Tamrat Abebe, Ashenafi Alemu, Berhanu Seyoum, Göte Swedberg, Alemseged Abdissa, Adane Mihret, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene
Title of paper: Bacterial profile of surgical site infection and antimicrobial resistance patterns in Ethiopia: a multicentre prospective cross-sectional study
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis by attending physicians; laboratory confirmation by wound discharge culture and identification (MALDI-TOF, Gram stain, biochemical tests)

Author: Worku Seble, Tamrat Abebe, Berhanu Seyoum, Ashenafi Alemu, Yidenek Shimelash, Marechign Yimer, Alemseged Abdissa, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene, Göte Swedberg, Adane Mihret
Title of paper: Molecular Epidemiology of Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus among Patients Diagnosed with Surgical Site Infection at Four Hospitals in Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis, confirmed by wound culture

Author: Worku Seble, Tamrat Abebe, Berhanu Seyoum, Bikila Alemu, Gebrie Denkayehu, Tamrayehu Seyoum, Dawit Hailu Alemayehu, Alemseged Abdissa, Getachew Tesfaye Beyene, Adane Mihret, Göte Swedberg
Title of paper: Molecular characterization of carbapenemase and extended spectrum beta-lactamase producing Acinetobacter baumannii isolates causing surgical site infections in Ethiopia
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Clinical assessment by surgeon: infection characterized by pain, redness, edema, tenderness, gaping, abscess/purulent discharge, fever >38°C within 30 days of operation for those without implant

Author: Wekesa Yvonne N, Fatuma Namusoke, Musa Sekikubo, Dennis Wandera Mango, Freddie Bwanga
Title of paper: Ceftriaxone- and ceftazidime-resistant Klebsiella species, Escherichia coli, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus dominate caesarean surgical site infections at Mulago Hospital, Kampala, Uganda
Method of SSI Diagnosis: Based on CDC criteria; clinical signs within 30 days of C/S, culture confirmation
